8.text:
Once upon a time,
there was a girl

11.text:
whose mother was dead
and whose father was dead.

14.text:
And who lived with her stepmother in
a little house beside a great dark forest.

19.text:
The girl and her stepmother
did not particularly get along.

23.text:
The stepmother was resentful
of the fact that she had to look

26.text: after this child who wasn't her own.

29.text:
As time went on, she got
angrier and angrier at the girl,

33.text:
despite the fact that
the girl was very obedient.

36.text:
Finally, it got to the point where
she just hated the girl, it was too much.

44.text:
While the girl was doing her chores,
the stepmother just turned to the girl

48.text: and she took a sieve from her kitchen,

50.text:
and she thrust it at her
stepdaughter and she said:

52.text:
"OK, this is what I need you to do:
I want you to go out into the world,

56.text:
I want you to take this sieve
to the Well of the World's End,

60.text:
fill the sieve with water,
and bring it back to me.

64.text:
And until you do, I do not
want to see your face ever again.

70.text:
Well, the girl could've argued,
but she was very obedient

74.text:
so she simply nodded and she took
the sieve and out into the world she went.

80.text:
She walked through the forest
and she walked through the fields,

82.text:
and over the hills and the mountains,
and she went from village to village

86.text:
until her clothing fell to rags and her
shoes were worn away from her feet.

92.text:
And everywhere she went
she asked the same question,

98.text:
"Have you heard of the
Well of the World's End?

100.text:
Do you know where I can find
the Well of the World's End?"

103.text:
And everywhere she went, everyone
she met gave her the same answer,

108.text:
"No, I'm really sorry but I've never
heard of the Well of the World's End.

112.text: I have no idea what that is."

114.text:
And so she just kept on
going and going and going.

119.text: One day she came to another forest

121.text:
and she was walking
through it down a little path and

124.text:
down the path in
the other direction came

128.text:
a little old woman carrying
her firewood on her back.

132.text:
And the girl did what she usually did,
she greeted the old woman,

136.text:
she talked about the weather
for a while, and then she came out

140.text: with the question she asked everybody,

142.text:
"Have you heard of the Well of the Worlds's
End?

144.text:
I really really need to find it
and it doesn't seem to be anywhere!"

149.text:
"Oooh!" said the little old woman.
"Actually, I do know where the

153.text:
Well of the World's End is,
you're almost there.

157.text:
Just keep on going down this path
and when you get to the crossroads,

161.text:
turn right and walk until you
come to the Well of the World's End."

166.text:
The girl was extremely happy to hear this
and she thanked the old woman

170.text:
and right away she went right down the path
and she walked down the path,

174.text:
she came to the crossroads, she turned
right and she kept walking and walking

178.text:
until the trees fell away
and there it was in front of her,

184.text:
a beautiful little wellspring,
the Well of the World's End.

189.text:
The girl fell to her knees before it,
finally she had gotten to where she was going.

193.text:
She took her sieve and
she dipped it into the water.

196.text:
But... the water ran out
the bottom of the sieve.

201.text:
And the girl couldn't believe it,
she tried it again and again

204.text:
and she just kept on dipping it into the water
and every time the water ran out the bottom.

209.text:
And she tried and tried and nothing
happened and finally she just threw herself

212.text:
to the ground in despair
and she began to weep.

217.text:
But as she lay there,
she heard a little voice,

222.text:
apparently speaking
right into her ear.

226.text:
And the voice said,
"Hello, why are you crying?"

232.text:
The girl got up and she looked
around and she couldn't see anyone,

236.text:
she'd have thought
she was completely alone

238.text:
and there seemed to be
no one there and she said

246.text:
The little voice said,
"Yeah, I'm right here, look down."

249.text:
And the girl did and
she looked down and there,

254.text:
on the banks of the
well, was a little green frog,

258.text: winking and blinking in the sunlight.

266.text: The frog said, "Hello to you too!

268.text:
I couldn't help but notice that you
seem to be a bit upset about something.

273.text: Is there anything I can do to help?"

275.text:
Well, the story just came
pouring out of the girl,

278.text:
"My stepmother, she sent
me out into the world

280.text:
and she said I had to go
to the Well of the World's End

282.text: and I have to take this sieve there,

284.text:
and I have to fill it with water from
the Well of the World's End

285.text:
and I looked and looked
and I couldn't find it and then

288.text:
finally I did find it
and it's a sieve, it's a sieve!

291.text:
And the water kept on running out of
the sieve and I just don't know what to do!"

296.text:
The frog listened to this very calmly,
consideringly, and then he said,

302.text:
"Ahhh that's interesting, I actually do
think I may have a solution for you.

307.text: However, it will come at a price.

310.text:
I will give you the solution
but you will have to make me a promise."

314.text:
"Oh anything!" said the girl.
"I will do anything you want!"

326.text:
"I will need you to promise me,
eventually, sometime in the future,

330.text:
to do my bidding for
an evening and a night."

335.text:
"I..I-..I mean yeah..
I thought it would be something a lot worse!

338.text:
Let's do that, please,
give me the solution!"

341.text:
The frog looked up at her
and he began to sing,

345.text:
"Pack it with moss my hinny, my heart,
pack it with moss my own true love.

351.text:
Remember this promise
that you've made to me.

354.text: Here at the Well of the World's End."

359.text:
And the girl tried it. She took the sieve
and she packed it with mud and moss

362.text:
and she dipped it into the water
and the water stayed in the sieve.

369.text:
The girl was so ecstatic about this
that she didn't even stop to thank the frog.

372.text:
She jumped up holding the sieve
stiffly before her, and she began to run.

376.text:
She ran through the forest, down the path,
she ran through the fields,

380.text:
and over the hills and the mountains
and through the villages,

382.text:
and she ran through
the forest near her house,

384.text:
and she ran, and she ran,
and she ran, not stopping day or night

386.text:
until she finally came
back to her stepmother's house.

388.text: "Here it is, finally I've got it!"

391.text:
The stepmother was
not really very happy to see the girl.

395.text:
She had been hoping she'd go out
into the world and never come back again.

399.text:
But what could she do, the girl had
obeyed her, she had done her task.

405.text:
"Alright" she said, and she welcomed
the girl back into the house.

408.text:
She took the water and she threw it away,
and they went back to their normal routine.

415.text:
Until that night,
when they sat down to dinner.

420.text:
The girl was, after her long
and arduous journey, very hungry,

424.text:
and looking forward to the meal.
And she saw the food, oh it's good food!

428.text:
She picked up her first bite
and she raised it towards her lips,

431.text:
but just then there came
a strange noise from the door.

434.text:
It wasn't quite a knocking,
it was more of a *scritch, scritch, scritch.*

439.text:
And the stepmother heard it and said,
"Did you hear something?

443.text: Is there someone at the door?"

445.text:
The girl had by this point forgotten
all about the frog and she just said,

448.text:
"No, no, I'm sure there wasn't.
I'm really hungry, let's- let's just eat."

453.text:
And she again raised
the food towards her mouth.

457.text:
"I'm sure there's someone at the door, there's
such a strange noise coming from over there!"

463.text:
"No, I'm sure it's just the wind,
it's just the wind, let's eat!"

466.text:
And again the girl raised
the food to her mouth.

469.text:
But this time,
a little voice began to sing:

473.text:
"Open the door my hinny, my heart.
Open the door my own true love.

478.text:
Remember the promise that you made to me,
down at the Well of the World's End."

487.text:
"Issss.. there something you're
not telling me" said the stepmother,

492.text:
"Is it possible that you made
somebody some kind of

495.text:
a promise when you were
at the Well of the World's End?"

499.text:
"Ummm.... mayyy-be.. it's possible there
was a conversation with a frog of some sort,

509.text:
you know I can't quite remember,
but maybe I may have promised to

513.text: do his bidding for an evening and a night,

515.text:
but it really doesn't matter,
let's, let's eat our-"

516.text:
"Oh no, no, no, no, no...
Girls must keep their promises!

521.text:
You go straight to that door and
you open it up and you let that frog in!"

529.text:
Well... there is a difference
between being at

532.text:
the Well of the World's End
and being really sad

534.text:
and wanting things to go right for you
and being at the end of your rope

537.text: and making a promise to the frog

540.text:
there's a difference between that and having
the frog in your house making demands of you.

543.text: The girl didn't really want to do this,

547.text:
the frogs are kind of slimy
and she would rather have not.

550.text:
But she did promise, she was very obedient,
and she knew what she had to do.

554.text:
She went to the door and she opened
it up and she let the frog in.

556.text: The frog hopped into the house.

560.text:
Well the girl went back to her meal,
decided that she would just ignore the frog,

565.text:
And once again she raised the bite to
her mouth and a little voice began to sing.

570.text:
"Lift me up softly my hinny, my heart.
Lift me up softly my own true love.

576.text:
Remember the promise that you made to me,
down at the Well of the World's End."

583.text:
"Hmmmm... no...
I realllly don't want to do that."

589.text:
"No, no, no, no, no!
Girls must keep their promises!

593.text:
You lift that frog up and you put
him right beside your plate right now!"

599.text:
The girl was very obedient.
She lifted up the frog as she

603.text:
put him right beside her plate,
and again she prepared to ignore him.

606.text:
She lifted the food towards
her mouth and a voice began to sing:

609.text:
"Give me some food my hinny, my heart.
Give me some food my own true love.

614.text:
Remember the promise that you made to me,
down at the Well of the World's End."

620.text:
"Mmmmmmm.. no I realllly, reallllly don't
want to do that!" said the girl.

627.text:
"No, no, no, no, no!
Girls must keep their promises!

632.text:
You feed that frog out
of your own hands right now!"

638.text:
She was very obedient.
The girl fed the frog with her own hands.

645.text:
She didn't eat much herself,
she had lost her appetite.

651.text:
The girl took the dishes and flung them
into the sink and then made a beeline

654.text:
for her room because she just
hoped that when she closed the door,

657.text: the frog would leave her alone.

660.text:
But she was brought up short
by a little voice singing,

664.text: "Take me to bed my hinny, my heart.

668.text: Take me to bed my own true love.

671.text:
Remember the promise that you made to me,
down at the Well of the World's End."

679.text:
"Hmmmmm...... I realllllly really really really really
don't want to, please don't make me do that!

693.text:
You take that frog and  you put
him right into your bed and

699.text: you  sleep with him all night!"

707.text:
She picked the frog up off the table, she ran
across the room, she ran into her bedroom,

710.text: she flung him down on the bed,

712.text:
she jumped into the bed herself,
she pulled up the covers around her,

715.text:
she got as far away from
the frog as she could,

717.text:
and she turned away from
him and closed her eyes

722.text: that nothing else would happen that night.

726.text: She must have slept a little bit,

728.text: because when she opened her eyes next,

731.text:
she turned in her sleep
and the first thing she saw

734.text:
was the frog on her pillow winking
and blinking at her in the dim, dim light.

740.text:
The night had almost passed,
the sun was not quite yet ready to rise.

747.text: The girl looked at the frog,

749.text: and the frog looked at the girl,

751.text:
and the frog once
more began to sing:

755.text: "Cut off my head my hinny, my heart.

759.text: Cut off my head my own true love.

763.text:
Remember the promise that you made to me,
down at the Well of the World's End."

774.text:
"No!", said the girl,
"No! I can't do that!

778.text:
Please don't ask me to
do that, it's not fair... to you.

783.text:
I couldn't do that to
someone who had helped me,

785.text:
just... ask me something else,
anything else,

789.text: But the frog just kept looking at her,

793.text: "Go get an axe and cut off my head."

797.text:
The girl begged and she pleaded
and she tried to reason with the frog

801.text: but it wouldn't listen to her,

805.text:
And finally, she went to
the shed and she got an axe.

811.text: She brought it back to the bedroom.

814.text: She looked at the frog and she said,

819.text:
And the frog just
looked at her and said,

823.text:
So the girl took the axe,
and she raised it above her head

827.text:
and she shut her eyes because she
didn't want to look at what she was doing.

830.text:
And she brought the axe down
as hard as she could on the frog.

835.text:
She kept her eyes closed
because she just didn't want to see.

839.text:
But finally she had to open them
and she cracked open her eyes.

844.text:
But what she saw was
not what she expected to see.

851.text:
In his place there was a
young man on the bed beside her,

854.text:
with the covers
drawn up around his chin.

861.text:
"What... what happened to the frog?
Who are you?"

875.text:
and I had to stay as a frog until a girl
did my bidding for an evening and a night,

885.text:
And now you have fulfilled these
requirements, and you've done that.

892.text: And he took her hand in his.

898.text:
the stepmother had been kind of gleeful
all night about thinking about her stepdaughter

904.text:
in bed with a frog and
how wonderful this was,

907.text:
and how, you know, the whole journey
had actually turned out quite well after all.

910.text:
And she just couldn't stand it any longer,
she had to go see this.

914.text:
So in the morning she tiptoed across
the room and she cracked open the door

922.text:
But in fact what she saw was the girl
in the arms of a beautiful boy

928.text: as the sun rose up in the morning.
